FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pipe serving coils machine room pipe, valves, & vessels

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Quik-To-Fix Foods operates as a further processing facility for food products such as chicken fried steaks, fajitas, chili, and other commodities used for human consumption.  The facility is located at 1130 North Expressway 77, Harlingen, Texas 78550.  The SIC code for the operation is 2013; the NAICS code is 311612.  The facility has approximately 130 full time employees.  The facility typically operates 10 hours per day, 5 days per week, and 50 weeks per year.  Staffing is greater during normal business hours due to the presence of management and administrative personnel.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The facility has developed and implemented a Process Safety Management Program (PSM) in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 as their accidental release prevention program.  The refrigeration system is monitored by technicians¿ onsite that are trained, qualified, and experienced in ammonia refrigeration in accordance with the facility¿s PSM program.  The system is visually inspected periodically for proper operation daily.  System parameters are logged in a permanent record, as are routine maintenance activities.  Utilizing general good operating procedures and providing appropriate training to employees will accomplish safe operation of the system.

This facility has developed and implemented a written Emergency Action Plan as defined in 29 CFR 1910.38 as their emergency response program.  This facility will utilize outside agencies and/or organizations to perform emergency response measures in the event of a fire, explosion or hazardous material release.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

This facility operates as a further processing facility for food products such as chicken fried steaks, fajitas, chili, and other commodities used for human consumption.  The facility utilizes an ammonia refrigeration system to kee

p products at storage temperature and preserve food safety standards.  The major components of the ammonia system are located in the mechanical room.  The system is a two-stage refrigeration cycle.  Support operations include a maintenance shop, forklift area, and administrative offices.

Anhydrous ammonia is listed as a hazardous chemical subject to the RMP regulation with a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.  The operating capacity of the system exceeds this threshold.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical ¿ Specific Prevention Steps

This facility complies with the provisions of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration¿s Process Safety Management Program 29 CFR 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agency¿s Risk Management Program 40 CFR 68.  The facility¿s PSM program includes provisions for process hazard analyses, management of change, pre-start up safety reviews, safe work, practices, inspections, testing, maintenance, compliance audits, and contractor qualifications.  Qualified outside contractors are used for construction and major repairs or modifications to the system.  The PSM program is reviewed annually and updated as necessary.  All significant changes to the system are reviewed in accordance with the PSM/RMP management of change provisions stated in the facility¿s plan.

 
Five Year Accident History

There is no reportable accident history that has occurred in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program

The facility has made arrangements with the local fire department and outside contractors to respond to emergencies involving anhydrous ammonia.  The facility conducts periodic drills.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility will upgrade and update safety programs as warranted or needed.

Quik¿To-Fix Foods has complied with the requirements of section 302 and 303 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA) by notifying the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC), the Local Em

ergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the Fire Department of the presence of ammonia at the site.  The facility files a Tier 2 Chemical Inventory each year with the SERC, LEPC and the Fire Department as required by sections 311 and 312 of EPCRA.  The facility's emergency action plan includes procedures for notifying the proper agencies in the event of a reportable release of ammonia.  A release of 100 pounds or more must be reported to the National Response Center, the SERC, and LEPC, in accordance with section 304 of EPCRA.
